awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Commercialization of a Decontamination Process for Powders for Transparent Ceramics
awd_abstract_narration:
A novel purification process has been developed and patented to reduce unwanted impurity content in ceramic powders. This process removes impurities such as sulfur and chlorine which have largely been neglected and cannot be removed by traditional purification processes utilized commercially. As a result, even the 'ultra-high purity' powders that are commercially available often contain significant amount of such impurities. The proposed purification process has been successfully applied to magnesium aluminate spinel (MgAl2O4), a material of choice for NASA and DOD for various defense and aerospace applications for which highly transparent and high strength materials are required. In comparison to the ballistic glasses, which are currently utilized for such applications, an improved ballistic performance at half the weight and thickness can be potentially achieved utilizing spinel. This will have a significant beneficial effect in various ways such as reducing the cost of maintenance and increasing the life-time of the components, energy/fuel savings and increase payload capacity of vehicles/spacecraft where spinel parts can be utilized. The proposed patented process has been successfully utilized in laboratories to consistently produce powders with impurity content that is sufficiently low for further processing, irrespective of impurity content in the starting powder. It is believed that the patented process will invigorate the commercialization of spinel by providing a cost-effective, scalable solution for the mass production of large monolithic bodies of spinel and other ceramics. This would benefit a large number of industrial manufacturers serving this market.

The novel purification process involves treating as received powders in ultra-high vacuum with or without concurrent heating for extended periods of time. The process does not modify the physical characteristics of the powders such as tap density or particle size distribution that are already optimized for specific applications. Utilizing the processed powders, it is possible to achieve near theoretical density and transparency in the spinel samples by hot-pressing only without the addition of any sintering aids. Current processing strategies involve use of sintering aids to achieve theoretical density and transparency that invariably lead to degradation of mechanical properties because of abnormal grain growth. Another processing step in the current processing strategies involves a post hot-pressing hot-isostatic pressing step at high temperatures to remove residual porosity. Although this step produces near theoretical transparency in the parts, it results in abnormal grain growth at the processing temperatures and significantly increases the production cost of the spinel parts significantly. The patented process can potentially avoid such complicating factors, but needs further evaluation to be efficient and viable at a commercial scale.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The primary goal of this project was to understand and assess the industry needs for a technology relevant to fabrication of transparent ceramics for demanding applications. In the course of this project the team interviewed close to one hundred potential customers, partners, domain experts to establish the value proposition for this technology and characterize and prioritize markets and customers. This is significant considering the narrow application for the technology within a very specific and complex market segment (the defense industry).

The following inferences were drawn from the market evaluation through the customer interviews.  

      1. The interview process indicated that the key value proposition of the decontamination technology, purity and reliability, is better aligned to a much smaller but high value add market segment in the form of optical ceramics rather than the perceived application as a better performing and cost effective alternative to bulletproof glass windows that are usually utilized in various defense applications. It was although the market for alternative technologies for bulletproof glasses is large, it is price-sensitive and the performance benefit using the technology will not be able to justify the increase in cost of production.

        2. The interview process also indicated that the defense applications might not be suitable for providing sustaining revenue to a company utilizing this technology. A suitable mass market application would be ideal for sustaining revenue.  Two such potential applications were identified: laser based LED lighting for vehicles and fracture resistant screens for portable electronics. The market for the first application is currently very dormant since only a few manufacturers are utilizing this technology for lighting (currently utilized for vehicle headlights only) but the demand can increase dramatically as the technology is adopted for numerous other applications. The second application is extremely price sensitive; the decontamination technology can potentially reduce the cost of production, but a detail cost analysis is required to evaluate the commercial viability for this technology.

Broader Impacts:

All these insights gained through the I-Corps project led us to believe that the current processing strategies for spinel need to be reevaluated, and a holistic approach is needed to develop a cost effective processing strategy. We envision a processing strategy that provides a cost savings at every stage, starting with a purer and consistent spinel powder, later adopting single step processing and avoiding the production losses and degradation of properties by avoiding lithium fluoride sintering aids. The purification process will add to the cost of production, but our estimates suggest that the benefits accrued will offset this cost increase. 

The program has provided an opportunity to interact with the entire supply chain and provided an all-encompassing view of the industry and their technical challenges. This has been proven to extremely helpful in determining future research directions not only in this primary area of research but the general approach towards fundamental research in materials science.
